description: Borrowed from French acerbité, from Latin acerbitās (“acerbity; harshness”), from acerbus (“bitter”). See acerb.

entries.meaning: Sourness of taste, with bitterness and astringency, like that of unripe fruit.

examples: acerbity of temper, of language, of pain

entries.meaning: (countable) Something harsh (e.g. a remark, act or experience).
examples: […]  the recollection of that yesterday  […]  made him bear with the meekness and patience of a true-hearted man all the worrying little acerbities of to-day;
